title: Metabolic labeling and LC-MS/MS-based identification of interleukin-1α-induced secreted proteomes from epithelial cells in the presence or absence of serum
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
      Culturing, treatment of cells, and collection of cell pellets and
      supernatants: Days 1–3
    
Timing: 2 days (for step 1)
    
Timing: 1 day (8 h) (for step 2)
    
These steps describe the handling and treatment of the HCT116 cells.
        Day 1–2: Seeding of the cells.
        
            Trypsinize HCT116 from a confluent dish and seed 5 × 106
            cells in new 145 mm cell culture dishes with 20 mL complete medium.
          
        Day 3: Stimulation, metabolic labeling and harvesting of cells and
        supernatants.
        
            Carefully wash cells three times in 10 mL warm DPBS to remove serum
            and methionine present in the medium.
          
            Cultivate cells in 10 mL methionine-free DMEM with no (0%) or 1%
            FBS. Add additional supplements (6 mM L-glutamine, 0.5 mM
            L-cysteine, 20 μg / mL streptomycin, 20 U / mL penicillin) to all
            samples.
          
            Stimulation, labeling, harvest:
            
                Add recombinant IL-1α (10 ng / mL) to half of the cells directly
                to the medium.
              
                In parallel to IL-1α stimulation, add 25 μM L-HPG or 25 μM
                L-methionine as a control, respectively, directly to the medium.
              
                Incubate cells in a humid atmosphere at 37°C with 5% CO2
                for further 6 h.
              
                Collect supernatants, transfer to 15 mL tubes and clear them at
                3000 × g at 4°C for 5 min (to remove dead cells or other
                debris). Continue with step 3 or freeze supernatants after
                transferring to a new tube.
              
Pause point: Supernatants can be
      frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80°C for several weeks.
    
Optional: Harvest the cells to analyze
      the nascent intracellular proteome in parallel to the secretome. For this,
      after collection of the supernatants, wash cells two times in 10 mL
      ice-cold PBS. Scrape cells in 1 mL PBS, transfer to 2 mL reaction tube and

centrifuge at 500 × g at 4°C for 5 min. Carefully discard
      supernatants and freeze cell pellet in liquid nitrogen and store at −80°C
      for several weeks.
    
Optional: Include treatment of cells
      with cycloheximide (5–10 μg / mL for 30 min) before metabolic labeling as
      an additional negative control. Cycloheximide strongly inhibits protein
      synthesis by interfering with translational elongation and should prevent
      any signals (upon Western blotting) arising from L-HPG labeling.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]
      It can also be used to estimate false positive IDs identified in the mass
      spectrometry analysis.
    
      Precipitation of proteins from supernatants and CLICK-chemistry-based
      biotinylation: Days 4–7
    
Timing: 16 h for precipitation, 2 h for
      washing at step 3
    
Timing: 2 h (for step 4)
    
Timing: 15 min (for step 5)
    
Timing: 2 h (for step 6)
    
Timing: 30 min (for step 7)
    
      These steps describe how proteins are recovered from the supernatants and
      biotinylated by a copper-catalyzed cycloaddition of biotin-azide (i.e.,
      the CLICK reaction).
    
        Day 4–5: Precipitation of proteins from supernatants (see
        Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2574-Fig2.jpg
              Figure 2. Precipitation of proteins from cell culture supernatants
            
Transfer supernatants to a new 50 mL tube.
            Slowly, add 40 mL of ice-cold acetone (−20°C) to 10 mL of
            supernatant using a glass pipette.
          
Incubate at −20°C for 16–22 h.
            Centrifuge at 15.000 × g at 4°C for 15 min, remove acetone.
          
            Add 2 mL cold (4°C) methanol, vortex, transfer sample to a new 2 mL
            reaction tube and centrifuge at 15.000 × g at 4°C for 15 min
            to further remove acetone.
          
Repeat step (e) to wash the precipitated protein pellet 2×.
Discard methanol and dry pellet at 18°C–22°C for 5 min.
            Resuspend pellet in 1 mL CLICK chemistry lysis buffer containing
            100 mM HEPES at pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 1% Nonidet P-40, 2 mM PMSF and

1× complete EDTA-free protease inhibitor mixture (Roche).
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2574-Fig3.jpg
                  Figure 3. A pre-clearing step reduces contaminating proteins
                  from supernatants of serum-starved cells but reduces protein
                  yields in the streptavidin pulldowns
                
                  HCT116 cells cultured in methionine-free DMEM / 0% FBS were
                  left untreated or were metabolically labeled with L-HPG.
                  Precipitated proteins from supernatants were pre-cleared with
                  streptavidin beads (lanes 1–3) or not (lanes 4–6). Then, CLICK
                  reactions were performed to biotinylate proteins. Aliquots of
                  supernatant proteins before (lanes 1, 2 and 4, 5) or after
                  purification on streptavidin beads (lanes 3, 6) were analyzed
                  by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting. Proteins on the membranes
                  were stained with Coomassie Brilliant blue (CBB, left panel)
                  and the biotinylated fraction was visualized using
                  streptavidin horseradish peroxidase (HRP) conjugates (right
                  panel). Compared to lane 6, proteins visible in lane 3 show
                  less CBB staining indicating that pre-clearing results in some
                  loss of (mostly unlabeled) protein in the final purified
                  samples.
                
Pause point: Step 3.c. Samples can
      be stored at −20°C for up to 2–3 days.
    
Pause point: Step 3.h. Samples can
      be stored at −80°C for several days.
    
Optional: A pre-clearing step with
      high capacity streptavidin beads may be included to reduce the background
      of contaminants (e.g. endogenously biotinylated or abundant “sticky”
      proteins) (see Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3] and troubleshooting,
      problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7]).
    
Optional: If enough protein is
      precipitated, the protein concentrations may be determined by standard
      assays such as Bradford or bicinchoninic acid (BCA) assay or more
      sensitive variants (Qubit protein assays).
    
Note: This step is crucial for the correct
      recovery of proteins from the cell culture supernatants.
    
Critical: This protocol uses acetone
      precipitation in the cold, however alternative methods such as ammonium
      sulfate (NH4)2SO4, trichloroacetic acid
      (TCA) or gel-filtration to precipitate or concentrate the protein fraction
      of the supernatants may also be used.

Day 6: CLICK reaction of precipitated supernatant proteins (see
        Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2574-Fig4.jpg
              Figure 4. CLICK reaction and precipitation/washing of proteins
              from the reaction mixture
            
            Freshly prepare the reagent mix for the CLICK reaction. For an
            equivalent of 1 mL supernatant you need to add 160 μL (1:7.25 v/v)
            to the precipitated protein pellet (approximately 1.16 mL in total).
          
            The reagent mix contains 6.25% SDS, 0.625 mM biotin-azide, 6.25 mM
            TCEP, 0.625 mM TBTA and 6.25 mM CuSO4.
            table:files/protocols_protocol_2574_35.csv
            Add 160 μL of this reaction mix to the sample to achieve 0.86% SDS,
            86 μM biotin-azide, 0.86 mM TCEP, 86 μM TBTA, and 0.86 mM CuSO4
            and incubate for 1.5 h at 18°C–22°C with slow rotation on an
            Intellimixer RM-2 (program F1, 22 rpm) or a similar rotating device
            (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
          
        Day 6: Precipitation of CLICK conjugates.
        
Transfer CLICK conjugate to 50 mL Falcon tubes.
            Slowly add 4 mL of cold acetone (−20°C) to 1 mL of CLICK conjugate.
          
Incubate at −20°C for 16–20 h.
Pause point: Samples can be kept at
      −20°C for 2–3 days.
    
        Day 7: Recovery of precipitated, biotinylated proteins (see
        Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
        
            Centrifuge at 15.000 × g at 4°C for 15 min; then remove
            supernatant.
          
            Add 2 mL cold (4°C) methanol, vortex, transfer to new 2 mL reaction
            tube and centrifuge at 15.000 × g / 4°C for 15 min to further
            remove acetone.
          
Repeat step b. to wash the precipitated protein pellet 2×.
            Discard methanol and dry protein pellet at 18°C–22°C for 5 min.
          
            Resuspend pellet in 60 μL 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.1% SDS in PBS (washing
            buffer I) at 18°C–22°C.
          
Pause point: Samples can be stored
      at −80°C for several days.
    
Optional: To remove CLICK reagents and
      free biotin-azide, an additional clearing and desalting step may be

included at this point. For this purpose, the precipitated proteins (lysed
      in 120 μL PBS containing 1% SDS) are passed through a 0.5 mL Zeba spin
      desalting column (Thermo Scientific) with a 7 kDa cutoff. However, we
      found that this step has the disadvantage of causing additional losses of
      supernatant proteins.
    
        Day 7: Adsorbance of biotinylated proteins on magnetic beads (see
        Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2574-Fig5.jpg
              Figure 5. Handling of magnetic streptavidin beads
            
            Resuspend the settled Pierce™ streptavidin magnetic beads by
            vortexing and transfer 30 μL (for Western blotting) and 40 μL (for
            mass spectrometry) for each sample in 1.5 mL reaction tubes.
            
Note: Use a cut-off 200 μL tip to
              transfer beads.
            
            Remove storage buffer using a magnetic device. Wait for 1 min until
            beads stick to the magnet.
          
            Equilibrate / wash the beads two times for 5 min with washing buffer
            I containing 500 μL 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.1% SDS in PBS at 4°C with
            slow rotation (22 rpm) on an Intellimixer (using mode F1) or a
            similar rotating device.
          
Remove buffer using the magnetic device.
            Add 25 μL (for Western Blot) or 35 μL (for mass spectrometry) of the
            supernatant proteins solubilized in 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.1% SDS in PBS
            (from step 6.e) to the beads and incubate for 16–22 h at 4°C with
            slow rotation on an Intellimixer RM-2 device (program F1, 22 rpm) or
            a similar rotating device.
          
Final processing of purified proteins: Day 8
Timing: 3 h (for step 8)
    
      This step describes the removal of unbound proteins and the purification
      of biotinylated proteins.
    
        Day 8: Purification of biotinylated proteins.
        
            Wash magnetic beads sequentially as follows. Use slow rotation on an
            Intellimixer RM-2 device (program F1, 22 rpm) at 4°C. Remove washing
            buffers using a magnet.

2 × with 500 μL PBS including 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.1% SDS (washing
                buffer I) for 10 min.
              
                3 × with 500 μL ice-cold PBS including 6 M Urea (washing buffer
                II) for 10 min.
              
3 × with 500 μL ice-cold PBS for 10 min.
            For Western blotting, add 30 μL 2× RotiLoad buffer and boil beads at
            95°C for 20 min. Transfer supernatants to new reaction tubes and
            discard beads.
          
            For nanoHPLC-MS/MS, add 60 μL of MS-buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.0,
            2 mM CaCl2) and transfer samples at 4°C to the mass
            spectrometry lab for on-bead trypsin digestion.
          
Pause point: Samples ready prepared
      for SDS-PAGE (step 8.b) may be stored at −20°C for one month.
    
Critical: For protein identification,
      we recommend transferring the samples (step 8.c) on ice directly to the
      mass spectrometry lab for further processing. Do not freeze the magnetic
      beads!
    
      Western blot to validate metabolic labeling and purification of proteins:
      Days 9–11
    
Timing: 2 days (for step 9)
    
      These steps describe the analysis of successful protein biotinylation by
      Western blotting as an important quality control.
    
        Days 9–11: SDS-PAGE, Western blotting and protein detection.
        
            SDS-Page.
            
Prepare a 12.5% separating gel.
                Overlay separating gel with 70% isopropanol and incubate for at
                least 20 min.
              
                Remove isopropanol and prepare a 5% stacking gel with a silicon
                comb inserted. Incubate for 10 min.
              
Remove the comb and fill chamber with 1× Laemmlie buffer.
                Load the equal sample volume (30 μL supernatants from beads) to
                the individual lanes of one gel.
              
Run the gel at 50 mA for 2.5 h.
            Western blotting (semi-dry).
            
                Cut four filter papers (Whatman) of the required size (e.g.,
                14 × 9 cm) for each gel.
              
Soak two of them in 1 × Western blot buffer.
                Cut the membrane (Roti-PVDF [Roth]) based on gel-size and

activate it in pure and fresh methanol for approx. 3 min.
              
                Equilibrate in 1 × Western blot-buffer together with the two
                filters.
              
                Place the separating-gel on top (carefully observe the correct
                orientation) and allow it to equilibrate shortly.
              
                Place the filter-membrane-gel stack on the bottom (+ pole) of
                the blotting-chamber.
              
                Place two more filters soaked in Western blot buffer on top of
                the stack.
              
                Put the lid (- pole) carefully on top and close the screws
                gently.
              
                Run the blot setup at 101 mA for 2 h (0.8 mA / cm2).
              
                After blotting, flush the membrane with desalted water to get
                rid of gel- and filter-fragments.
              
Block the membrane for 16–22 h with 5% BSA in TBS-T.
            Detection of (nascent) proteins (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2574-Fig6.jpg
                  Figure 6. Western blot analysis of proteins in supernatants of
                  starved (0% FBS) and non-starved (1% FBS) cells before and
                  after streptavidin pulldown
                
                  (A and B) HCT116 cells cultured in methionine-free DMEM
                  without (0%) or with FBS (1%) were left untreated or were
                  stimulated with 10 ng / mL IL-1α for 6 h and were
                  metabolically labeled with L-HPG for the final 5 h as
                  indicated. Precipitated proteins from supernatants were
                  biotinylated by CLICK reactions in vitro. Aliquots of
                  supernatant proteins before (lanes 1, 2 and 5, 6) or after
                  purification on streptavidin beads (lanes 3, 4, 7, 8) were
                  analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting. Proteins on the
                  membranes were stained with Coomassie Brilliant blue (CBB,
                  left panel) and the biotinylated fraction was visualized using
                  streptavidin horseradish peroxidase (HRP) conjugates (right
                  panel). Highlighted in panel (A) is the very prominent protein
                  band of bovine serum albumin (BSA) that is, however, not
                  labeled with L-HPG as shown in panel (B).
                
                Incubate membrane with streptavidin-HRP conjugates (1:5000 in 5%
                BSA in TBS-T).

Wash membrane four times with TBS-T for 5 min.
                Develop blot using ECL detection reagents. For this purpose,
                incubate membrane in ECL reagent for 1–2 min. Remove ECL reagent
                and wrap in clear film.
              
                Measure ECL signals using the ChemiDoc instrument or a similar
                device.
              
            Coomassie staining (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
            
Stain membrane in Coomassie solution for approx. 10 min.
                Destain membrane with Coomassie destaining solution three times
                for 10 min.
              
Dry membrane and take a picture.
Pause point: Step 9.a.iii.
      Polymerized SDS gels can be stored at 4°C for 16–48 h.
    
Pause point: Blocked blot membranes
      can be incubated in blocking solution or primary antibodies for 16–22 h at
      4°C and ECL reactions performed and developed the next day.
    
Note: Western blot membranes need to be
      stained with Coomassie Brilliant Blue (CBB) or Ponceau S Red to visualize
      the transferred proteins and to judge overall protein yield and protein
      loading (see Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]). Alternatively, a more
      sensitive silver staining protocol can also be used to stain proteins in
      the SDS gel directly after electrophoresis.
    
Note: In addition to the validation of the
      biotinylation patterns (see Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]), the blot
      membranes can be incubated with primary antibodies directed against known
      / expected or new target proteins as identified by LC-MS/MS.
    
Optional: Alternatively to the
      detection by HRP-streptavidin, nascent proteins may be visualized directly
      within the SDS gel by in-gel fluorescence by using
      tetramethylrhodamine-azide (TAMRA) in the CLICK reaction as described in
      Forester et al.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]
Critical: It is important to validate
      the specific biotinylation patterns in all samples that received L-HPG
      compared to methionine prior to LC-MS/MS to ensure that the metabolic
      labeling has worked (see Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] as example).
    
On beads tryptic digest and nanoHPLC-MS/MS: Days 8–10
Timing: 1 day (for step 10)
    
Timing: 1 day (for steps 11 and 12)

Timing: 1–2 days (for step 13)
      These steps describe the sample processing prior to LC-MS/MS analysis and
      the instrument settings and run conditions using a timsTOF Pro mass
      spectrometer in the mass spectrometry laboratory.
    
        Day 8: On-bead digest.
        
            Remove buffer from the streptavidin magnetic beads obtained at Step
            8.c.
          
            Add 0.1 μg trypsin solubilized in 50 μL of MS-buffer to each sample
            and incubate for 45 min at 37°C.
          
            Transfer supernatant to fresh tubes using the magnetic separator to
            precipitate the beads and continue incubation of the supernatant at
            37°C for 16–22 h.
          
Note: It is recommended to prepare a
      trypsin working solution for all samples that are processed in parallel by
      diluting the trypsin stock solution (0.5 μg / μL) in an according volume
      of MS-buffer and add 50 μL of this working solution to each of the
      samples.
    
Critical: Do not perform the initial
      on-bead digest step for more than 45 min, because this will lead to the
      digestion of a substantial amount of streptavidin and the resulting
      peptides will interfere with the subsequent mass spectrometric analysis.
    
Critical: The final digest should be
      further processed directly at the next morning to prevent over digestion
      and formation of artifacts.
    
        Day 9: Reduction and alkylation of tryptic peptides.
        
            Reduction of peptides.
            
                Add DTT to a final concentration of 5 mM to the tryptic peptide
                solution.
              
Mix the sample and incubate for 15 min at 95°C.
            Alkylation of sulfhydryl-groups:
            
Add iodoacetamide to a final concentration of 25 mM.
                Mix the sample and incubate for 45 min at 18°C–22°C in the dark.
              
Add DTT to a final concentration of 50 mM.
Mix the sample and incubate for 1 h at 18°C–22°C.
Note: Reduction and alkylation of peptides
      is not absolutely necessary, but recommended to increase peptide coverage.

Day 9: Purification and concentration of peptides using solid-phase
        extraction (SPE).
        
            Equilibration of C18 SPE centrifuge-columns.
            
Add 150 μL acetonitrile (buffer 1) onto the column.
                Place the column in a 2 mL tube and centrifuge for 30 s at
                300–400 × g.
              
Discard the flowthrough.
                Add 150 μL double distilled H2O / 0.1% TFA (buffer 2)
                onto the column.
              
                Place the column in a 2 mL tube and centrifuge for 30 s at
                300–400 × g.
              
Discard the flowthrough.
Repeat steps iv. – vi. in total 3 ×.
            Peptide binding and washing.
            
                Pipet the peptide solution on the column and centrifuge for
                2 min at 300–400 × g.
              
Discard the flowthrough.
                Add 150 μL of 5% acetonitrile / 0.1% TFA (buffer 3) onto the
                column and centrifuge for 2 min at 300–400 × g.
              
Discard the flow through.
Repeat steps iii. and iv. in total 3 ×.
            Elution of purified tryptic peptides.
            
Place the column in a fresh 2 mL tube.
                Add 150 μL 50% acetonitrile / 0.1% TFA (buffer 4) and centrifuge
                for 1 min at 300–400 × g.
              
Repeat step ii and combine eluates.
Concentrate and dry peptides in a vacuum concentrator.
Pause point: Eluted peptides can be
      stored at 4°C for one week or at −20°C for several weeks.
    
Optional: Other purification and
      concentration methods (e.g. Zip-Tips) may be used.
    
Note: Purification and concentration of
      peptides is dependent on the nanoHPLC-setup used. It can be e.g. omitted
      when using a system with a Trap-column.
    
Note: In case the peptide volume is larger
      than the capacity of the column, it can be repeatedly loaded in
      appropriate fractions. For this purpose, repeat steps a.i. and a.ii. as
      often as necessary with suitable sample volumes.
    
Critical: Do not exceed the peptide
      binding capacity of the columns used.

Day 9–10: Mass spectrometric analysis.
        
            Solubilize and dilute peptides.
            
Resuspend peptides in 25 μL LC-MS/MS loading buffer.
                Measure peptide concentrations using a Nanodrop™ device using
                the OD of 280 nm.
              
                Dilute the samples according to a suitable concentration
                depending on the specification of the mass spectrometer. For the
                timsTOF Pro 100 ng / μL is a good value as loading of 200 ng of
                peptides per run is recommended.
              
            Place samples in the autosampler of the mass spectrometer and choose
            suitable separation and data-acquisition methods depending on the
            equipment used.
          
Note: For the timsTOF Pro mass
      spectrometer, the built-in DDA_PASEF standard 1.1 sec_cycletime is
      recommended for data acquisition using a HPLC gradient of water / 0.1%
      formic acid (solvent A) and acetonitrile / 0.1% formic acid (solvent B)
      running for 100 min at a flow rate of 400 nL / min. The chromatography
      proceeds with a linear increase from 2% B to 17% B within 60 min, followed
      by a linear gradient up to 25% solvent B within 30 min and a linear
      increase up to 37% solvent B for an additional 10 min. Finally, solvent B
      is increased to 95% within 10 min and hold for an additional 10 min. Here,
      we used a column temperature of 50°C on a nanoElute nanoHPLC-system
      equipped with a 25 cm Aurora column but other settings may be used
      according to the usage of alternative LC-MS/MS instrument set ups.
